subject: Test with no @Test inside, was Re: Test with no class inside
msgSnippet: Dear Kent, Thanks for your help. It seems that if you want to run a class as a JUnit test from inside Eclipse you must have at least one method defined with
messageBody:
Dear Kent,

Thanks for your help.

It seems that if you want to run a class as a JUnit test from inside
Eclipse you must have at least one method defined with the @Test
annotation somewhere in your class. It means that, in your example, you
would not be able to execute the "Sub" class directly as a JUnit test.
As Joe B. Rainsberger said later in the thread, It is probably a problem
with Eclipse and I will try to work around it.

Al

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Kent Beck" <kentb@...> wrote:
>
> Dear Al,
>
> What you are trying to do makes good sense. However, I wasn't able to
> reproduce your error. Here is the test case that works for me:
>
> public class InheritedTestTest {
> public abstract static class Super {
> @Test public void nothing() {}
> }
> public static class Sub extends Super {}
>
> @Test public void subclassWithOnlyInheritedTestsRuns() {
> Result result= JUnitCore.runClasses(Sub.class);
> assertTrue(result.wasSuccessful());
> }
> }
>
> What error message are you seeing?
>
> Regards,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
>

>
> Hi,
>
> Is it possible to have a test class without any tests inside its body
> (e.g. with no @Test annotation inside) ? It's because I've created an
> abstract class containing all my tests and I extend this class for
> each implementation that I have to test. By doing this, I don't need
> to write redundant code to test different kind of implementations. To
> help you better understand, I give you an example :
>
> public abstract class FirstTest {
>
> @Test
> public test1() {
> // ...
> IFactory factory = getFactory();
> // ...
> }
>
> @Test
> public test2() {
> // ...
> IFactory factory = getFactory();
> // ...
> }
>
> protected abstract IFactory getFactory();
>
> }
>
> /*
> * This class should be considered a test class even there is no
> * @Test inside. Normally, it inherit all the test methods from
> * the superclass.
> *
> */
> public class Implementation1Test extends FirstTest {
>
> protected IFactory getFactory() {
> return new MyFirstImplementationFactory();
> }
>
> }
>
> Now, if I try to run Implementation1Test as a JUnit test, Eclipse
> reports me an error. I have to specify at least one @Test annotation
> in my concrete test class. Is there anybody who can help how to do
that ?
>
> Thanks,
> Al
